attributes.description: Alan Mathison Turing was an English mathematician, computer scientist, logician, cryptanalyst, philosopher and theoretical biologist. He was highly influential in the development of theoretical computer science, providing a formalisation of the concepts of algorithm and computation with the Turing machine, which can be considered a model of a general-purpose computer. Turing is widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science.
Julius Mathison Turing was Alan Turing's father who worked in the Indian Civil Service (ICS) of the British Raj government at Chatrapur.
Ethel Sara Turing was Alan Turing's mother, daughter of Edward Waller Stoney, chief engineer of the Madras Railways. She was from a Protestant Anglo-Irish gentry family.
John Ferrier Turing was Alan Turing's elder brother and father of Dermot Turing, 12th Baronet of the Turing baronets.
The department where Alan Turing obtained his PhD in June 1938.
The place in London where Alan Turing was born on 23 June 1912.
A place in the United Kingdom where Turing stayed during childhood while his parents traveled between the UK and India.
The location where Turing's parents purchased a house in 1927, and where Turing lived during school holidays.
The location of Baston Lodge, Upper Maze Hill, where Turing stayed during childhood.
The university where Turing studied from September 1936 to July 1938, mostly under Church.

A mathematical model of computation that defines an abstract machine that manipulates symbols on a strip of tape according to a table of rules. It can be considered a model of a general-purpose computer.
A notion included in Turing's proof, now known as a universal Turing machine, with the idea that such a machine could perform the tasks of any other computation machine.
A concept introduced in Turing's dissertation, 'Systems of Logic Based on Ordinals'.
A notion introduced in Turing's dissertation, in which Turing machines are augmented with so-called oracles, allowing the study of problems that cannot be solved by Turing machines.

attributes.description: Turing's PhD dissertation that introduced the concept of ordinal logic and the notion of relative computing.
A primary school at 20 Charles Road, St Leonards-on-Sea, where Turing was enrolled from the age of six to nine.
An independent school in the village of Frant in Sussex where Turing was educated between January 1922 and 1926.
An independent boarding school in the market town of Sherborne in Dorset, where Turing boarded at Westcott House from 1926, at the age of 13.
Alan Turing was born on 23 June 1912 in Maida Vale, London.
In June 1938, Turing obtained his PhD from the Department of Mathematics at Princeton.
Alan Turing was the son of Julius Mathison Turing.
Alan Turing was the son of Ethel Sara Turing.
Alan Turing had an elder brother, John Ferrier Turing.
Alan Turing was born in Maida Vale, London, on 23 June 1912.
During childhood, Turing stayed in Hastings while his parents traveled between the UK and India.
At Hastings, Turing stayed at Baston Lodge, Upper Maze Hill, St Leonards-on-Sea.
Turing lived in Guildford during school holidays, where his parents purchased a house in 1927.
From September 1936 to July 1938, Turing spent most of his time studying under Church at Princeton University.
In June 1938, Turing obtained his PhD from the Department of Mathematics at Princeton.
Turing's dissertation, 'Systems of Logic Based on Ordinals', introduced the concept of ordinal logic and the notion of relative computing.
Turing provided a formalisation of the concepts of algorithm and computation with the Turing machine.
Turing's proof included a notion of a 'Universal Machine', with the idea that such a machine could perform the tasks of any other computation machine.
Turing's dissertation introduced the concept of ordinal logic.
Turing's dissertation introduced the notion of relative computing, in which Turing machines are augmented with so-called oracles.
Turing's parents enrolled him at St Michael's, a primary school at 20 Charles Road, St Leonards-on-Sea, from the age of six to nine.
Between January 1922 and 1926, Turing was educated at Hazelhurst Preparatory School.
In 1926, at the age of 13, Turing went on to Sherborne School, where he boarded at Westcott House.
The dissertation 'Systems of Logic Based on Ordinals' introduced the concept of ordinal logic.
The dissertation 'Systems of Logic Based on Ordinals' introduced the notion of relative computing with oracle machines.
The concept of a Universal Machine (universal Turing machine) generalizes the Turing machine to perform tasks of any other computation machine.
Student at Sherborne School who formed a significant friendship with Christopher Morcom.
Fellow pupil at Sherborne School who has been described as Turing's first love.
Christopher Morcom's mother, with whom Turing maintained a relationship long after Christopher's death.
The school where Turing met and formed a friendship with Christopher Morcom.

attributes.cause: Complications of bovine tuberculosis, contracted after drinking infected cow's milk
attributes.description: The death of Christopher Morcom which caused Turing great sorrow.

attributes.content_excerpt: I am sure I could not have found anywhere another companion so brilliant and yet so charming and unconceited. I regarded my interest in my work, and in such things as astronomy (to which he introduced me) as something to be shared with him and I think he felt a little the same about me ... I know I must put as much energy if not as much interest into my work as if he were alive, because that is what he would like me to do.
attributes.description: Letter from Turing to Christopher Morcom's mother expressing his grief and determination to continue their shared interests.

attributes.content_excerpt: I expect you will be thinking of Chris when this reaches you. I shall too, and this letter is just to tell you that I shall be thinking of Chris and of you tomorrow. I am sure that he is as happy now as he was when he was here. Your affectionate Alan.
attributes.description: Letter written by Turing to Frances Morcom a day before the third anniversary of Christopher's death.

entities2.label: Letter about Spirit to Frances Morcom

attributes.content_excerpt: Personally, I believe that spirit is really eternally connected with matter but certainly not by the same kind of body ... as regards the actual connection between spirit and body I consider that the body can hold on to a 'spirit', whilst the body is alive and awake the two are firmly connected. When the body is asleep I cannot guess what happens but when the body dies, the 'mechanism' of the body, holding the spirit is gone and the spirit finds a new body sooner or later, perhaps immediately.
attributes.description: Later letter from Turing to Frances Morcom expressing his beliefs about spirit and matter.
Turing's belief at this point in his life in concepts such as a spirit, independent of the body and surviving death.
An interest that Christopher Morcom introduced to Alan Turing.
Philosophical positions that some have speculated were caused in Turing by Morcom's death.
At Sherborne, Turing formed a significant friendship with fellow pupil Christopher Collan Morcom, who has been described as Turing's first love.
Alan Turing was a student at Sherborne School.
Christopher Morcom was a student at Sherborne School.
Christopher Morcom died on 13 February 1930 from complications of bovine tuberculosis.

attributes.response: working harder on shared scientific and mathematical topics
attributes.description: The event caused Turing great sorrow. He coped with his grief by working that much harder on the topics of science and mathematics that he had shared with Morcom.

attributes.nature: letters from Turing, gifts from Frances
attributes.description: Turing's relationship with Morcom's mother continued long after Morcom's death, with her sending gifts to Turing, and him sending letters, typically on Morcom's birthday.
Turing wrote a letter to Morcom's mother expressing his grief and determination.

attributes.occasion: Day before third anniversary of Morcom's death
attributes.description: A day before the third anniversary of Morcom's death (13 February 1933), Turing wrote to Mrs. Morcom.

attributes.subject: beliefs about spirit and matter
attributes.description: In a later letter, also written to Morcom's mother, Turing wrote about his beliefs regarding spirit and matter.
The letter was addressed to Frances Morcom, Christopher's mother.
The anniversary letter was addressed to Frances Morcom, Christopher's mother.
The letter about spirit was addressed to Frances Morcom, Christopher's mother.
Christopher Morcom was interested in astronomy and introduced it to Alan Turing.
Their relationship provided inspiration in Turing's future endeavours.
Christopher Morcom introduced Alan Turing to astronomy.
At this point in his life, Turing still believed in such concepts as a spirit, independent of the body and surviving death.
Some have speculated that Morcom's death was the cause of Turing's atheism and materialism.
British mathematician, computer scientist, and logician who made significant contributions to theoretical computer science.
Mathematician to whom Turing sent the first draft typescript of his investigations on decidability problems.
Mathematician who published work with similar conclusions to Turing's on decidability problems and developed lambda calculus.
Mathematician and physicist who acknowledged that the central concept of the modern computer was due to Turing's paper and wanted to hire Turing as his postdoctoral assistant.
Mathematician who wrote a report for the committee evaluating Turing's work for fellowship.
Mathematician whose incompleteness theorems were reformulated by Turing in his work on computable numbers.
German mathematician who originally posed the Entscheidungsproblem (decision problem) in 1928.
Mathematician who had already proven in 1922 the version of the central limit theorem that Turing proved in his dissertation.
The college where Turing studied as an undergraduate and was later elected as a Fellow.
The university where Turing studied under Church and obtained his PhD.
The department from which Turing obtained his PhD in June 1938.

attributes.description: The journal in which Turing published his first paper and later his paper on computable numbers.
Turing's undergraduate dissertation that proved a version of the central limit theorem.

entities3.label: Equivalence of left and right almost periodicity

attributes.publication_venue: Journal of the London Mathematical Society
attributes.description: Turing's first published paper.

entities3.label: On Computable Numbers, with an Application to the Entscheidungsproblem

attributes.publication_venue: Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society
attributes.publication_dates: first part on 30 November 1936, second part on 23 December 1936
attributes.significance: easily the most influential math paper in history
attributes.description: Paper in which Turing reformulated Gödel's results and introduced what became known as Turing machines.

entities3.label: An Unsolvable Problem of Elementary Number Theory

attributes.author: Alonzo Church
attributes.description: Church's paper with similar conclusions to Turing's then-yet unpublished work.

entities3.label: Systems of Logic Based on Ordinals

attributes.description: Turing's PhD dissertation that introduced the concept of ordinal logic and the notion of relative computing.
Formal and simple hypothetical devices introduced by Turing that became central to the theory of computation.
A machine that could perform the tasks of any other computation machine, now known as a universal Turing machine.
The problem of determining whether a Turing machine will ever halt, which Turing proved to be undecidable.
The decision problem originally posed by David Hilbert in 1928, which Turing proved had no solution.
The thesis that Turing machines and the lambda calculus are capable of computing anything that is computable.
A concept introduced in Turing's PhD dissertation.
A notion introduced in Turing's PhD dissertation, in which Turing machines are augmented with so-called oracles.
A formal system developed by Church that, like Turing machines, is capable of computing anything that is computable.
A theorem in probability theory that Turing proved a version of in his undergraduate dissertation.
Fellowship position to which Turing was elected on the strength of his dissertation.
Visiting fellowship held by Turing during his second year at Princeton.
A device that Turing built during his time at Princeton.
Turing studied the undergraduate course in Schedule B from February 1931 to November 1934 at King's College, Cambridge, where he was awarded first-class honours in mathematics.
Turing started his master's course (Part III) in Spring 1935, which he completed in 1937.
Turing was elected a Fellow of King's College on the strength of his dissertation where he served as a lecturer.
From September 1936 to July 1938, Turing spent most of his time studying under Church at Princeton University.
Turing was a Jane Eliza Procter Visiting Fellow during his second year at Princeton.
In June 1938, Turing obtained his PhD from the Department of Mathematics at Princeton.
Turing's dissertation, On the Gaussian error function, written during his senior year and delivered in November 1934, proved a version of the central limit theorem.
Turing published his first paper, a one-page article called Equivalence of left and right almost periodicity.
Turing finished and delivered his 36-page paper for publication called 'On Computable Numbers, with an Application to the Entscheidungsproblem'.
Turing's dissertation, Systems of Logic Based on Ordinals, introduced the concept of ordinal logic and the notion of relative computing.
In addition to his purely mathematical work, Turing studied cryptology and also built three of four stages of an electro-mechanical binary multiplier.

attributes.work: first draft typescript on decidability problems
attributes.description: In mid-April 1936, Turing sent Max Newman the first draft typescript of his investigations.

attributes.work: On Computable Numbers, with an Application to the Entscheidungsproblem
attributes.description: Turing reformulated Kurt Gödel's 1931 results on the limits of proof and computation, replacing Gödel's universal arithmetic-based formal language with the formal and simple hypothetical devices that became known as Turing machines.

attributes.work: On Computable Numbers, with an Application to the Entscheidungsproblem
attributes.description: Turing's paper included a notion of a 'Universal Machine' (now known as a universal Turing machine), with the idea that such a machine could perform the tasks of any other computation machine.
Turing proved that there was no solution to the decision problem by first showing that the halting problem for Turing machines is undecidable.
Turing proved that there was no solution to the decision problem (Entscheidungsproblem).

attributes.work: Systems of Logic Based on Ordinals
attributes.description: Turing's dissertation introduced the concept of ordinal logic.

attributes.work: Systems of Logic Based on Ordinals
attributes.description: Turing's dissertation introduced the notion of relative computing, in which Turing machines are augmented with so-called oracles.
Turing spent most of his time studying under Church at Princeton University.
Church published his An Unsolvable Problem of Elementary Number Theory, with similar conclusions to Turing's then-yet unpublished work.
Church developed the lambda calculus, which like Turing machines, is capable of computing anything that is computable.

attributes.specific_aspect: central concept of the modern computer
attributes.description: John von Neumann acknowledged that the central concept of the modern computer was due to Turing's paper.

attributes.outcome: Turing went back to the United Kingdom
attributes.description: John von Neumann wanted to hire him as his postdoctoral assistant, but he went back to the United Kingdom.

attributes.evaluation: if published before Lindeberg's work, would have been 'an important event in the mathematical literature of that year'
attributes.description: Abram Besicovitch's report for the committee went so far as to say that if Turing's work had been published before Lindeberg's, it would have been 'an important event in the mathematical literature of that year'.
Turing reformulated Kurt Gödel's 1931 results on the limits of proof and computation.
The Entscheidungsproblem (decision problem) was originally posed by German mathematician David Hilbert in 1928.
This version of the theorem Turing proved in his paper had already been proven, in 1922, by Jarl Waldemar Lindeberg.
Turing's dissertation proved a version of the central limit theorem.

attributes.publication_dates: first on 30 November and the second on 23 December 1936
attributes.description: It was published in the Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society journal in two parts.
Turing's first paper was featured in the tenth volume of the Journal of the London Mathematical Society.
Turing's dissertation introduced the concept of ordinal logic.
Turing's dissertation introduced the notion of relative computing with oracle machines.
The universal Turing machine generalizes the concept of a Turing machine to perform the tasks of any other computation machine.
Turing proved that the halting problem for Turing machines is undecidable.
According to the Church–Turing thesis, Turing machines and the lambda calculus are capable of computing anything that is computable.
